nodes.text: Infinite exponential economic growth is essential for the survival and conservation of our economy and civilization
The anti-growth perspective assigns ontological primacy to entropy and equilibration and therefore concludes infinite growth is impossible
The pro-growth perspective relies on mind-matter dualism that treats mental production as immune to entropy, a stance lacking rational or empirical justification
A parsimonious, inclusive frame centers the universal process of creation (emergence of new, more powerful levels of organization) as the fundamental driver of growth and conservation
Second law of thermodynamics implies entropy production is nonnegative but does not forbid maintaining entropy production at zero, and entropy includes equilibration that can enable new organization
Theoretical and empirical work shows equilibration (entropy production) can produce higher-level organization and disequilibrium that creates new structure, not only disorder
Mental operations originate from physical sensory-motor processes and therefore involve energy exchanges and forms of entropy production; mental creation is not ontologically separate

Combinatorics of operations implies exponential growth in possible combinations (n to n squared pattern) but also implies exponential depletion of the resource of disequilibrium at a given level; empirical work (Bloom et al.) shows ideas are getting harder to find, productivity per researcher declines exponentially
Production, consumption, resource depletion, and population dynamics are empirically correlated and display exponential behavior that requires a unifying explanation

Because new levels of organization create access to new resources and because equilibration of n operations yields about n squared combinations, sustaining current regulatory levels requires continuous exponential creation of higher levels; failure produces exponential productivity decline, resource depletion, and population pressure

Policy implication: organize economic and social practice consciously around the process of creation—cultivate inclusion, manage and translate new mental-level organizations into material production—since technology alone is necessary but insufficient

Applying a creation-centered economic organization that harnesses human creative capacity and integrates mental and material levels enables infinite exponential growth and thus conserves civilization; technocratic fixes alone cannot substitute for this systemic shift
